note_models.name: Basic-509a3

fields: Do you know where this Anki deck originated?

This deck is part of an open collaborative effort started by YYC Net Lab. This deck is provided free of charge and without warranty. For updates please see the link below. If you notice any errors or would like to add some cards please reach out to YYC Net Lab through Github.

To stop seeing this card click on 'More' in the bottom right and select 'Suspend Card'.
A circuit that contains both resistance and capacitance.
What is the abbreviated name for a circuit with both capacitance and resistance?
A circuit with both a resistor and an inductor.
What is the abbreviation for a circuit with both an inductor and a resistor?
For RL circuits, how is time constant calculated?
T - the time constant for an RL circuit.
How do you calculate the time constant for an RC circuit?
T - the time constant for an RC circuit.
What is the value of the micro prefix?
What is the value for the nano prefix?
What is the value of the pico prefix?
In an RC circuit, what does one time constant represent?
The time required to charge/discharge a capacitor 63.2%.
In an RC curcuit what term describes the time taken to charge a capacitor to 63.2% of capacity
In an RL circuit what occurs in one time constant?
Current can increase to 63.2% of the maximum value.
What term describes how long it takes for current to increase to 63.2% of the maximum value in an RL circuit?
A voltage that opposes the applied voltage.  Typical in inductors.
With inductors, what is the term that is used to describe the opposing voltage?
What percentage occurs at two time constants?
What percentage occurs at three time constants?
What unit is used for capacitance?
What happens when a current passes through a wire?
Thumb points in the direction of electron flow.  Fingers wrap around the conductor and indicate the North pole.
What rule can be used to determine the direction of the magnetic field based on the electron flow?
What term is used for energy stored in an electromagnetic or electrostatic field?
How can potential energy be stored in a RLC circuit?
What exists between charged plates of a capacitor?
Where can you find an electrostatic field?
Between charged plates of a capacitor.
What unit is used to measure inductance?
How does increasing quality factor affect bandwidth?
If a narrow bandwidth is required, what needs to happen to the quality factor?
What is the effect of adding a resistor to a parallel resonant circuit?
Decrease the Q and increase the bandwidth.
How can you decrease the Q and increase the bandwidth of a parallel resonant circuit?
What two elements are common in semiconductors?
Where are Silicon and Germanium commonly used?
When is gallium arsenide used in semicondictors?
What semiconductor is suitable for high speed microwave devices?
What type of semiconductor material has fewer free electrons than its base material?
In a P-type semiconductor, what is the relative number of free electrons?
What type of material has more free electrons than its base material?
What is the relative number of free electrons in an N-type semiconductor?
What are the charge carriers in P-type semiconductor materials?
What semiconductor type uses Holes as the charge carrier?
What are the charge carriers in N-type semiconductor materials?
What semiconductor type uses free electrons as the charge carrier?
Silicon in its pure form has what electrical property?
What semiconductor in its pure form is considered an insulator?
What do you call an element with properties of both a conductor and insulator?
Why are certain elements called semiconductors?
They have properties of both conductors and insulators
What does the doping process introduce to a semiconductor?
What process adds impurities to a semiconductor?
What is the principle characteristic of a Zener diode?
What device has constant voltage under varying current?
What diode varies its internal capacitance as the applied voltage changes?
What is the principle characteristic of a varactor?
Capacitance changes as the applied voltage changes
What is a typical application for a hot carrier diode?
What diode is well suited for VHF/UHF mixers and detectors?
What limits the maxiumum forward current in a junction diode?
What effect does junction temperature have on a diode?
What are the major ratings for a diode?
Max forward current and peak inverse voltage
For what device type are max forward current and peak inverse voltage major ratings?
What are the two main structures for diodes?
The two main structures for diodes
What is the typical application for a point-contact diode?
What type of diode could be used for an RF detector?
What is a common use for a PIN diode?
What device can be used as an RF switch?
In a bipolar transistor - what is alpha?
Change in collector current with respect to the emitter current
What term describes the change in collector current with respect tot he emitter current?
What is the beta of a bipolar transistor?
The change in collector current with respect to base current
What term describes the change in collector current with respect to the base current?
What component conducts from a negative emitter to a positive collector when its base voltage is positive?
What happens in an NPN transistor when the base is made positive?
It conducts from the negative emitter to the positive collector.
What are typical values for alpha for a transistor
What transistor metric describes delta Ic over delta Ie and is always less than one?
What is the alpha of a bipolar transistor in a common base configuration?
What defines the forward current gain of a bipolar transistor in a common base configuration?
In a bipolar transistor, what is the term to describe the change of collector current with respect to base current?
In a bipolar transistor, what does Beta describe?
The change in collector current with respect to the base current.
What configuration specifies the alpha of a bipolar transistor?
What is specified for a common base BJT configuration?
What configuration specifies the beta of a BJT?
What is specified for a BJT in a common emitter or common collector configuration?
What component conducts electricity from a positive emitter to a negative collector when its base is made negative?
What happens when the base of a PNP transistor is made negative?
It conducts electricity from a positive emitter to a negative collector
Express Alpha in terms of Beta
Express Beta in terms of Alpha
What is the current gain of a BJT in common emitter or common collector compared to a common base configuration?
What BJT configuration results in very high current gain?
What is an enhancement mode FET?
It is a FET without a channel.  Gate voltage is proportional to current.
What type of FET has no channel?  Gate voltage is required for current flow.
What is a depletion mode FET?
A FET with a channel.  Current flows without a gate voltage.
What FET has a channel?  Current flows without gate voltage.
What is the purpose of the built-in gate protective zener diode in a MOSFET?
Prevent the gate insulation from being punctured by small static charges or excessive voltage.
How can a MOSFET protect the gate insulation from being punctured by small static charges or excessive voltage?
Why are special precautions necessary in handling FET and CMOS devices?
What devices are particularly susceptable to ESD?
How does the input impedance of a FET compare with that of a BJT?
The FET has high input impedance.  The BJT has low input impedance
What is different regarding impedance of FETs and BJTs?
FETs have high input impedance.  BJT has low input impedance.
What are the three pins on a FET?
Where are the Gate, Source, and Drain pins found?
What are the two basic types of FET
N-Channel and P-Channel are two types of what?
Electron conduction in a MOSFET occurs in what channel type?
What type of conduction occurs in N-Channel MOSFETS?
Hole conduction in MOSFETs occurs in what channel type?
What type of conduction in MOSFETs occurs in P-Channel?
What are the three terminals of a silicon controlled rectifier?
Where do the Anode, Cathode, and Gate pins occur?
What are two stable operating conditions for an SCR?
Conducting and non-conducting are two stable states of what?
When an SCR is triggered, to what other semiconductor diode are its electrical characteristics similar?
What device is similar to a junction diode when triggered?
What are the layers in an SCR
What device has the layers PNPN?
When does an SCR exhibit electrical characteristics similar to a forward-biased silicon rectifier?
When the gate of an SCR is On, what is it characteristicly similar to?
To what family does the SCR belong?
What is a member of the Thyristor family?
When is an SCR commonly used?
What is commonly used in a power supply crowbar circuit?
For a given transformer secondary voltage, what rectifier has the highest averate output voltage
What is the benefit of a bridge rectifier?
Highest average output voltage for a given transformer secondary voltage.
For a half-wave rectifier what is the worst cast PIV in terms of RMS?
Explain why the PIV can be 2.8 times RMS in a half-wave rectifier
Because the delta-V between the positive cycle and negative cycle compound
What is the PIV of a full-wave center-tap power supply in terms of RMS?
Explain why the PIV of a full-wave center-tap power supply is 2.8 times RMS.
The center provides the reference and the delta-V from the ends of the secondary coil can be negative.
